titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Richard Neville Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:24

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (68 boxes) + 1 art, 10 broadside, 2 record album storage, 1 roll
did.abstract: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, notebooks, scrapbooks, photographs, printed materials, artwork, audiovisual materials, and digital media by or related to Richard Neville. The papers document Neville's career as a writer and counterculture leader, especially his work on the Sydney and London versions of the underground magazine Oz. Scrapbooks, correspondence, transcripts, writings, and other papers document Neville's obscenity trials in Australia and England and later dramatizations of the trials. Writings also document Neville's later work for publications such as Rolling Stone. Photographs and papers document Neville's family and childhood in Australia. The collection also includes artwork and other papers relating to Oz art director Martin Sharp.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Richard Neville on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2011.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 68, 69, 72, and 73 (audiovisual materials): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 70 (digital media): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 71: Restricted until 2042. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Richard Neville Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richard Neville Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Richard Clive Neville (1941-2016)
bioghist.p: Richard Clive Neville, an Australian author associated with the counterculture movement of the 1960s and 1970s, was born in Sydney on December 15, 1941. He co-published Oz magazine, an underground magazine that was the subject of high-profile obscenity trials in Australia and the United Kingdom. Neville died on September 4, 2016, in Byron Bay, Australia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, notebooks, scrapbooks, photographs, printed materials, artwork, audiovisual materials, and digital media by or related to Richard Neville. The papers document Neville's career as a writer and counterculture leader, especially his work on the Sydney and London versions of the underground magazine Oz. Scrapbooks, correspondence, transcripts, writings, and other papers document Neville's obscenity trials in Australia and England and later dramatizations of the trials. Writings also document Neville's later work for publications such as Rolling Stone. Photographs and papers document Neville's family and childhood in Australia. The collection also includes artwork and other papers relating to Oz art director Martin Sharp.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Papers, 1742-2011. II. Audiovisual materials, 1967-1968. III. Electronic media. IV. Restricted Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed "To Richard with best wishes from Betty Cowper, 15 Dec. '41", which is Richard Neville's birthday. This album holds the earliest Neville family images.

did.unittitle: Rychard Carrington's "Cultural and Ideological Challenges of the London Underground Movement 1965-1971"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Neville is mentioned throughout, particularly within Chapter Two. Also contains a conference programme, "The Permissive Society and it's Enemies", from the 15th Summer Conference of the Institute of Contemporary British History, July 9-11, 2001, and a copy of Rychard Carrington's paper "The Ludic Liberalism of Richard Neville".

did.unittitle: Richard Neville's letter from Wandsworth Prison

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains Richard Neville's prison notebook, Obscene Courtroom Dramas invitation, Backlash Oz Appeal handbill, Oz Obscenity Trial procession handbill, Presenting The Oz Obscenity Trial, Hate Mail, Oz Obscenity Trial stickers, and Ozjets d'Art - Clytie Jessup fundraising catalogue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains: medical reports; a probation officer's report; "Social Enquiry" reports; Richard Neville's statement to the court; a letter from the publisher F. Warburg declining to give evidence; signed witness letters; two summonses regarding Oz 28 "Schoolkids Issue"; a typescript of Richard Neville's letter to his family regarding Oz 28; a marked up photocopy of Richard Neville's opening at the appeal; reflective "opinion" by Geoffrey Robertson on Richard Neville's 1972 conviction for possession of marijuana; marked up legal papers from the firm of Offenbach & Co. concerning legal representation and court transcript of matters involving Richard Neville, Oz and prohibited substances; profile of Judge Argyle; US Embassy letter regarding visa; Document of Identity; and Immigration act documents and cuttings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes to John Mortimer, as well as typescript notes for the appeal. Also contains notes regarding Fatty Arbuckle, notes regarding Judge Argyle's comments in court, and extensive strategy notes for witness testimony and cross examination.

did.unittitle: Richard Neville's Oz Trial notebook, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains eight bundles of trial transcripts which are marked up in preparation of the appeal by Geoffrey Robertson and John Mortimer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains comprehensive press cuttings, photographs and ephemera, as well as correspondence between Richard Neville and Andrew Fisher and material for and from a recent London celebration of Fisher's life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published by the National Times of Sydney in February 1975. Comments on Sydney, Australia's bohemians - "the Push" - and provides an insight into how the group shaped the intellectual life of the whole city.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains, on page 22, a story relating to the appearance of the Oz editors in a London magistrates court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains the Orientation Week issue, edited by Alex Popov and Michael Robertson. The back page features a full page cartoon by Martin Sharp, "The Gas Lash", which resulted in the arrival of the Vice Squad on campus. The editors were prosecuted for obscenity and later acquitted. Paper also contains a half page add for Oz magazine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a copy of the September 1964 issue, which covers the prosecution of Sydney Oz magazine and the jail sentences handed out to Richard Neville, Martin Sharp and Richard Walsh.

did.unittitle: Passport and travel documents - Archibald MacKnight

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains the album of Bertha Fanning, Betty Neville's mother. The label reads: "Concert reviews, Programs, gossip, etc from 1895-1905 including her London tour and her mysterious return to Sydney..." Includes programs, handbills, press notices, reviews, notes, correspondence and confirmations. Also includes an envelope labelled "fragments from a notebook by Berthe McKnight (nee Fanning) recalling her childhood in Newcastle in the 1870s written for her children".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a photograph of Dalton Thomas Walker Neville, receiving a war medal. The caption reads "1000 marks - dead or alive". Also included are his 1969 obituaries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed by Martin Sharp, circa 2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains her journalism. The inside cover has Betty Neville's address, phone number and a note to return if found.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 29 photographs, including Andrew Fisher in SUDS, Richard Neville at Nimbin, Ken Neville (uncle), Louise Ferrier, Paul Jordan Smith (cousin), Betty Neville, Anne Cayzer, Suzette Markwell, Colonel Neville, and two transparencies -by Greg Weight- of Richard Neville on POL shoot, circa 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 17 photographs of the Neville Family, most notably Josie, Jill and children, and one portrait of Jill, July and Richard on the day of Richard Neville's arrival in London, September 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 25 prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains facsimile copies of Tharunka, as well as copies of "the arty wild oat", volumes 1 and 2 (1962). It also contains the first issue of "Nimbin Good Times", which was produced as a guide to the forthcoming 1973 Aquarius Festival. The subsequent "Nimbin Good Times" issue is also included, volume 1, No. 1 (27 March 1973).

did.unittitle: "Country Life: For Vital Rural News and Views" - billboard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: According to Richard Neville, this billboard is "the last relic / memento of the newspaper my father eventually managed".

Trials of Oz poster; Taste of Oz poster; two states of the Oxford Playhouse production (4 pieces)
Cylinder annotated "Digital copies of Oz posters from Felix Denning" (7 pieces)
Cylinder annotated "Negatives of 'Hippie Hippie Shake' images (1995) Bloomsbury Edition" (4 pieces)
Large group of photostat copies relating to issue 28 "School Kids Issue"
Packet containing 5 x digital scans, printed newspaper banners of Oz Trial; Felix Dennis Archives - 13 x original newspaper banners.
Materials relating to Oz magazine - digital reproductions of covers and art boards
Materials relating to Oz magazine - posters
